title: What makes a good musical (Broadway or not) and how do musicals get popular? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think there are some critical elements to make musicals successful. A love story. There must be two characters that make the audience want to see get together and live happily ever after.The setting should be interesting, but the show should NOT be about the setting. South Pacific is set in WWII, but is not about WWII. You would not describe West Side Story as being about New York, even though it is set in New York.Songs that are beautiful and catchy, that people will leave the theater humming, with interesting lyrics that are written by someone with talent in writing lyrics. This is an offen overlooked aspect of shows.There are exceptions. Cats has such great tunes that it succeeded despite having no plot or love story. It is a dance review with a cat theme. If you’re Andrew, you can pull that off. I think, however, that his shows with love stories—Aspects of Love, Phantom, etc. are better. And some shows with great music can succeed with only a great plot or strong central character.Shows get popular when people see them and like them. They are “tried out” in small venues, and if audiences are enthusiastic, more money comes in for a bigger tryout. Finally, if lots of money comes in, they make it to Broadway or London.

A great story line, wonderful characters, and fantastic music that moves the plot along, and has memorable melodies that people will be humming as they leave. As far as popularity, word of mouth, and media; commercial or social, are probably the best indicators if a show will be successful.

7yI’v seen many … and have directed several (at a community-theater level) IMO, it certainly does not have to be the story or storyline … some of the most famous musicals barely hang together in this way. Showboat … Oklahoma … South Pacific … to name just a few. So … I’d say it takes one-or-more of the following four things: Three+ great songsOne great song, plus several really good onesOne really-great hit songA memorable lead character (I mean the actor or actress playing it)
